articles.headline: U.S. Hopes to Ease G.M. to Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: The government is seeking to avoid court chaos by persuading at least some creditors to agree to a plan that would cleave General Motors into two pieces.
articles.abstract: The government is seeking to avoid court chaos by persuading at least some creditors to agree to a plan that would cleave General Motors into two pieces.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government may seek to ease General Motors into what it calls a “controlled” bankruptcy, somewhere between a prepackaged bankruptcy and court chaos, by persuading at least some creditors to agree to a plan that would cleave the company into two pieces, according to people briefed on the matter.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Jonathan D. Glater

articles.headline: Cerberus Tries to Get Chrysler Out of a Ditch
articles.snippet: Cerberus Capital Management has agreed to give up its 80.1 percent stake in Chrysler, and the private investment firm is now trying to save its investment in GMAC and Chrysler Financial.
articles.abstract: Cerberus Capital Management has agreed to give up its 80.1 percent stake in Chrysler, and the private investment firm is now trying to save its investment in GMAC and Chrysler Financial.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Stephen A. Feinberg, the long road back from the most disastrous investment of his career  Chrysler L.L.C.  began last week around a polished wood table inside the Treasury Department.

articles.headline: In Europe, ‘Cash for Clunkers’ Drives Sales
articles.snippet: A plan that provides government subsidies to drivers who junk their old jalopies for new cars has exceeded expectations.
articles.abstract: A plan that provides government subsidies to drivers who junk their old jalopies for new cars has exceeded expectations.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia  The economy here may be in free fall, but anxiety about the future did not stop Vilo Hrivnak from driving his 12-year-old green hatchback to the junkyard a few days ago and promptly buying his first new car, a cappuccino-colored Skoda.

articles.headline: Chinese Inmates at Guantánamo Pose a Dilemma
articles.snippet: The Obama administration must decide whether 17 Uighurs are innocent refugees or dangerous terrorists.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration must decide whether 17 Uighurs are innocent refugees or dangerous terrorists.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ilshat Hassan’s flight from China has brought refuge, a job at the consulting firm Booz Allen and an apartment in the Virginia suburbs.
articles.byline: By William Glaberson and Margot Williams

articles.headline: Stimulus Thinking, and Nuance
articles.snippet: European leaders are resisting calls for stimulus measures, but history shows that they often work.
articles.abstract: European leaders are resisting calls for stimulus measures, but history shows that they often work.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every so often, history serves up an analogy that’s uncomfortable, a little distracting and yet still very relevant.

articles.headline: In Europe, Obama Faces Calls for Rules on Finances
articles.snippet: Germany and France want global financial regulations that could reach inside America’s borders, while President Obama is pushing for more stimulus.
articles.abstract: Germany and France want global financial regulations that could reach inside America’s borders, while President Obama is pushing for more stimulus.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  In his first full day in Europe, President Obama conceded Wednesday that the United States had “some accounting to do” for failures that led to the world’s financial crisis, even as he tried to brush past heavy pressure from Germany and France to accept global financial regulations that could reach well inside American borders.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Justice Dept. Moves to Void Stevens Case
articles.snippet: The Justice Department moved to drop charges against Ted Stevens, citing prosecutorial misconduct.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department moved to drop charges against Ted Stevens, citing prosecutorial misconduct.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department moved on Wednesday to drop all charges against former Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska, who lost his seat last year just days after being convicted on seven felony counts of ethics violations.

articles.headline: Funds Tied to Madoff in Legal Vise
articles.snippet: Massachusetts’ top securities regulator has sued Fairfield Greenwich Advisors, which directed billions of dollars of its clients’ money into Bernard L. Madoff’s investment firm.
articles.abstract: Massachusetts’ top securities regulator has sued Fairfield Greenwich Advisors, which directed billions of dollars of its clients’ money into Bernard L. Madoff’s investment firm.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Bernard L. Madoff waits in jail to be sentenced, legal problems are accumulating for some of the hedge fund managers who helped him raise billions of dollars from around the world for what he now admits was a vast Ponzi scheme.
